text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days.
Let me start by breaking down the problem step by step.
First, I know that the man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
That makes sense because taking the elevator down would save him time compared to walking up or down the stairs, especially if he's starting from the 10th floor.
In the evening, when he returns home, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.
So, that means on a normal day, he's getting off at the 7th floor and then walking up three flights to the 10th.
I wonder why he doesn't just take the elevator all the way up to the 10th floor every time, both in the morning and evening.
Now, the twist is that on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
That's different from his usual routine, so there must be a reason related to the weather.
Maybe the stairs are slippery when it's raining, so he doesn't want to walk up them.
That would make sense because walking on wet stairs can be dangerous, especially if they're not well-maintained.
But wait, he's already taking the elevator down in the morning.

If the stairs are slippery in the evening, why doesn't he just take the elevator all the way up on rainy days? Maybe because when it's raining in the evening, he's coming back from work, and the elevator might be crowded or he's in a hurry, so he takes the elevator part of the way and then walks the rest.
But on rainy days, perhaps he's avoiding the stairs entirely by taking the elevator all the way up.
Another angle to consider is the building's elevator policy.
Maybe on rainy days, the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor, so he has to take the stairs after that.
But that doesn't fit because the problem says he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days, so the elevator must be fully functional.
I'm also thinking about the time factor.
Maybe the elevator takes longer to go up, but on rainy days, he's in a hurry and doesn't want to wait for the elevator to go all the way up.
However, that seems less likely because the problem doesn't mention any issues with elevator speed or frequency.
Perhaps it's about the effort of walking up the stairs.
On rainy days, he might not want to get his clothes wet by walking through the wet stairwell, especially if he's in a hurry or doesn't have appropriate footwear.
So, taking the elevator all the way up keeps him dry.

Another possibility is that the building's management has a policy where on rainy days, the elevator is only available up to a certain floor, but that doesn't align with the problem statement because he's still taking the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
Wait, maybe it's about the number of floors he has to walk.
On normal days, he walks up three floors, but on rainy days, he might prefer not to walk any floors at all, hence taking the elevator all the way.
That makes sense because walking, especially in wet conditions, can be uncomfortable or unsafe.
So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days because walking up the stairs would be slippery and potentially dangerous.
Therefore, he avoids the stairs by taking the elevator the entire way to stay dry and safe.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor on rainy days because walking up the stairs would be slippery and unsafe.
By using the elevator, he avoids the wet and slippery conditions, ensuring he remains dry and safe.
